conclusion: Introduction to the problem with point light source S emitting Light A and B, forming illuminated areas.
Description of the refractive indices n1 and n2 for Light A and B, and the task to find the sine value of the refraction angle for Light B.
Light A and B originate from point source S beneath the water surface.
When lights strike the water surface, they refract into the air with different angles due to different refractive indices.
Circular areas on the water surface are illuminated due to the refraction of these lights.
Definition of incident angle θi in water and refraction angle θ in air.
Application of Snell's Law: n sin(θi) = sin(θ).
Refractive index n2 corresponds to Light B.
Application of Snell's Law for Light B: n2 sin(θi) = sin(θ).
Expression for sine of refraction angle θ: sin(θ) = n2 sin(θi).
Illuminated circular area on the water surface is related to refraction angle θ.
At the boundary of the small circular area, light undergoes total internal reflection, meaning θi is the critical angle.
Critical angle θc for total internal reflection: sin(θc) = 1/n2.
At the boundary of the small circular area, sin(θ) = n2 sin(θc) = 1.
Conclusion that sin(θ) = 1 indicates refraction at 90°, corresponding to the critical angle for total internal reflection.
